La conexión con el mundo natural era profunda, y sentían cómo cada respiración enlazaba su existencia con el ciclo vital de la tierra. A medida que se acercaban a la cima, no solo se elevaban físicamente, sino también en conciencia y aliento. en_results: never dared to avow it. The consciousness of innocence is the only security which a person can have against the accusations of the world;
en_results_raw: never dared to avow it. The consciousness of innocence is the only security which a person can have against the accusations of the world; and when that consciousness is supported by the approbation of those whose opinion is worth having, it must be extremely difficult to unsettle the firm belief of its possessor." Marianne continued, her voice carrying the conviction of her own sense of rightness, "My actions, though they may seem hasty or imprudent to others, were guided by my genuine feelings and an honest desire to express them. I believe that sincerity and openness are virtues that should not be lightly dismissed or judged harshly. Society often values conformity over authenticity, but I choose to live by my principles, even if it means standing alone at times. In doing so, I hope to find true happiness and avoid the regrets that come from stifling one's true self for the sake of appearances. I am confident that my actions, though they may not always align with conventional wisdom, are rooted in a sincere and pure intention to connect with others and to experience life fully. Therefore, I hold fast to my convictions, secure in the knowledge that my integrity remains unblemished."

es_results: segundo principio. Mi corazón decidió que iba a actuar contra toda razón. No pude soportar la idea de perderla para siempre.
es_results_raw: segundo principio. Mi corazón decidió que iba a actuar contra toda razón. No pude soportar la idea de perderla para siempre. Busqué oportunidades, llamé a amigos, incluso consideré ir a buscarla mi mismo. La idea de su sonrisa desaparecerse de la vida era demasiado dolorosa para soportar. La determinación me consumió, me impulsó a hacer cosas que nunca imaginé. En mi mente, todo era posible si solo podía alcanzarla de nuevo. La locura de amor me dominó, me llevó a lugares sin pensar en los riesgos. Pero nada me detenía, nada me paraba. Elinor era mi todo, y si algo iba a hacer, sería todo lo posible para recuperarla. La noche anterior, mientras me preparaba para ir a buscarla, un pensamiento inesperado me asomó: ¿qué haría si ella ya no quería volver? Ese pensamiento me paró en mi tracks, dejándome con un sentimiento de vacío y incertidumbre. La búsqueda se transformó en un viaje interior, un viaje para encontrar la paz interior que había perdido al decidir seguir adelante con mi plan. La noche estaba caída, pero mi mente no podía descansar. Reflexioné sobre cada acción tomada, cada decisión tomada en el impulso. ¿Era justo? ¿Era digno de ella? Estas preguntas me inundaban, dejándome con una conciencia tormentosa de lo que estaba por hacer. La elección era mía y la consecuencia, inevitable. Pero en ese instante de claridad, un cambio se produjo en mi corazón. La obsesión, la frenética necesidad de recuperar a Elinor, comenzó a disminuir. Comprendí que, quizás, lo más importante era no solo recuperarla, sino también respetar su voluntad. La verdadera amada no es quien nos consume, sino quien nos libera para crecer. Así que, con un corazón lento y un paso incierto, decidí dejar ir esa ruta peligrosa y comenzar a buscar la paz, no solo para mí, sino para ambos.

Mẹ đang cố gắng giúp anh phát hiện ra cách thích ứng tốt với thay đổi, bằng cách cung cấp sự hỗ trợ, sự ủng hộ và thuyết phục. Anh nhận ra rằng việc thay đổi không phải là hậu quả của một thay đổi ngoại hình mà là một thay đổi từ bên trong, từ cách nhìn và cách sống của mình. Anh cảm thấy mình cần phải tăng cường sự tự tin để thích ứng với những thay đổi đáng kể, và mẹ là nguồn cảm hứng quan trọng trong quá trình này. Anh nhận ra rằng sự hiểu biết và sự ủng hộ của mẹ sẽ giúp anh trải qua những khó khăn này một cách tốt hơn, và anh sẽ cố gắng hơn để học cách chịu đựng và thích ứng. Anh cảm thấy mình hứng thú về việc thực hiện nhiệm vụ này, vì nó không chỉ giúp anh phát triển cái nhìn của mình mà còn giúp mình trở nên mạnh mẽ hơn. El aire frío se entrecortaba con el aroma de tierra humeda y humedad, un olor que me transportaba aún más lejos de mi realidad, sumergiéndome en un mundo donde solo existía en ese momento presente, consciente de la eternidad que flotaba ante mis ojos. Las aves canto con fervor, sus melodías añadiendo capa de vida al silencio de la madrugada. Cada nota era una bendición, cada voz un recordatorio de que, aunque el día llegara a terminar y la noche regresara a envolver al mundo en su manto oscuro, la belleza de ese momento único permanecería en mi memoria, un faro que iluminaría mi camino por los años venideros. Así, en medio de la quietud de la madrugada, encontré una profunda gratitud por la capacidad de apreciar estas pequeñas maravillas, sabiendo que, aunque impermanentes, son eternas en el corazón.

en_first_half: "It is very true," said Marianne, "that admiration of landscape scenery is become a mere jargon. Every body pretends to feel and tries to describe with the taste and elegance of him who first defined what picturesque beauty
en_second_half: was. I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and meaning."
en_results: is; but few possess the genuine feeling, or the power of expressing it with grace and propriety. The term is bandied about so freely, that it is become almost as common as the air we breathe, and yet it
en_results_raw: is; but few possess the genuine feeling, or the power of expressing it with grace and propriety. The term is bandied about so freely, that it is become almost as common as the air we breathe, and yet it is not half so universally appreciated. People talk of picturesque beauty with a sort of pedantic solemnity, as if they were pronouncing a Latin or Greek word, which they do not understand, but are determined to master. They affect to be charmed with every rugged hill, every wild valley, and every irregular line of a landscape, merely because it has been called picturesque by some celebrated writer or artist. They do not inquire whether the scene before them is really pleasing to the eye or not; they only repeat the cant phrase, and fancy that they are thereby proving their taste and sensibility. In reality, however, the true lover of nature is not to be deceived by such empty pretensions; he knows that there is a vast difference between the mere use of a fashionable term, and the sincere, heartfelt admiration of a beautiful view. The latter feeling is deep and lasting; it fills the soul with a tranquil ecstasy, and imparts a joyous enthusiasm that words can scarcely express. It is a sentiment that elevates and ennobles the mind, and makes us feel our own insignificance in the presence of the mighty works of creation. On the other hand, the affected admiration of the superficial observer soon fades away, like a passing shadow, leaving no trace behind. It is a mere passing fancy, a transient emotion, which vanishes as soon as the fashionable phrase is no longer in vogue. In short, the genuine love of landscape scenery is a noble passion, deserving of all respect and encouragement; but the empty and pedantic use of the term picturesque beauty is a mere mockery of taste, and ought to be discountenanced and discouraged.

en_results_raw: to be exercised. She could not, therefore, admire the composure of Willoughby, or regret the warmth of her own feelings. She saw no merit in his coldness, nor any fault in her own impetuosity. She considered the latter as a natural consequence of her situation, and the former as a defect in his heart; and in this judgment, she was not at all influenced by the opinion of the world, which generally applauded the one and censured the other. She had, indeed, a very high sense of propriety, and a strong inclination to do as she believed right; but this inclination was not so much a matter of principle, as a part of her temperamental disposition. She was not guided by rules, but by feelings; and her feelings, in this instance, were decidedly in her favour. She could not, therefore, be persuaded to think herself in the wrong, or to condemn her own behaviour. She was, however, sensible that her sister did not see the matter in the same light, and this difference of opinion was the source of much of their disagreement. Marianne's disposition was lively, impetuous, and fond of excitement; while Elinor's was calm, reflective, and averse to unnecessary agitation. This contrast in their characters often led to disputes, especially when Marianne's impetuosity carried her into actions that Elinor considered imprudent or ill-judged. Despite their differences, however, the sisters shared a deep affection for each other, and their bond was strengthened by the mutual understanding and support they offered in times of trouble. In the end, Marianne's strong convictions and passionate nature remained unaltered, but her experiences and relationships gradually helped her to temper her actions with a greater degree of consideration for others.

La señora Jennings, con su actitud desafiante, no parecía estar dispuesta a negociar o buscar una solución pacífica. en_results_raw: her story. She sat down, her hands trembling, and her eyes cast down, as if the very act of recounting her ordeal was a physical burden. Her voice, when she finally spoke again, was barely above a whisper, laden with a sorrow that seemed to stretch back through time, touching every moment of her life. She spoke of a day that had begun like any other, filled with the mundane tasks and quiet joys of daily existence, unaware that it would spiral into a nightmare. The sun had been shining, casting a golden hue over the familiar streets, a deceptive serenity that masked the storm brewing within her world. It was during the afternoon, when shadows grew long and the air felt heavy, that the first sign of trouble appeared. A knock at the door, unexpected and insistent, pulled her from her chores. Opening it, she found a figure cloaked in anonymity, their face obscured by a hood, their presence a menacing silhouette against the fading light. Without a word, they pushed past her, their intent clear even before they vanished into the depths of her home. Panic surged through her veins, a primal fear that rooted her to the spot for a heartbeat before she sprang into action. She raced from room to room, calling out, but there was no response, no sign of the intruder. Her heart pounded in her chest, a frantic drumbeat of dread. She searched every corner, her hands trembling, her mind racing through possibilities. It was then she discovered the note, a single sheet of paper, scrawled with chilling words that promised retribution. The realization hit her like a physical blow, a cold dread that settled in the pit of her stomach. The intruder was not after her possessions, nor her home; they were after her, after something she possessed within. The note hinted at a threat, a demand for something invaluable, something irreplaceable. As she clutched the paper, her world narrowed to that single piece of parchment, the ink a stark contrast to the white, the words a sinister promise of chaos to come. The hours that followed were a blur of frantic calls to the police, desperate attempts to reach anyone who might help, but the sense of isolation grew with each unanswered call. She barricaded herself in her bedroom, the door reinforced with furniture, her heart pounding in her ears as she listened for any sign of movement. The night was long, filled with whispered prayers and silent tears, each passing minute an eternity of fear. When dawn finally broke, casting a pale light through the curtains, she dared to venture out. The house was silent, untouched, but the sense of intrusion lingered, a ghostly presence that made her skin crawl. The police arrived, their arrival a beacon of hope in the darkness of her ordeal, but the relief was short-lived. They found no evidence of a break-in, no signs of forced entry, nothing to substantiate her claims. The note, of course, had disappeared, leaving her with nothing but her word against the void. The investigation stalled, her pleas fell on deaf ears, and the sense of being dismissed, of being labeled a liar, was a wound that festered. The ordeal left her shattered, her faith in justice and the safety of her home shattered. The calm she had tried to regain was a fragile thing, easily shattered by the smallest reminder of that day. Now, as she recounted her tale, her eyes lifted, meeting those of her listener with a raw, unfiltered plea for understanding and belief. Her story was a testament to the fragility of peace and the enduring strength required to face the abyss of fear and emerge, if not unscathed, then defiant. She spoke no longer of hope for resolution, but of the necessity to bear witness, to ensure that her experience, though dismissed by the authorities, was not forgotten or disbelieved. In sharing her story, she sought not only solace but also a kind of vengeance, a way to reclaim her narrative from the shadows where it had been cast. Her voice, though quivering, was resolute, a declaration that even in the face of overwhelming adversity, she would not be silenced.

Bu nedenle, onun aşkıyla yaşanan her deneyim, onun kişisel gelişimini ve hayatının anlamını derinleştirmeye yardımcı olabilir.

No podía permitirse abdicar de su responsabilidad, especialmente cuando la vida de tantos dependía de ella. Se dirigió hacia el armario, donde sabía que encontraría lo que necesitaba para enfrentar la situación. Con el corazón latiendo con fuerza, abrió los cajones y encontró el arma que sabía usar. Su mente estaba clara, aunque llena de angustia; sabía que tenía que tomar una decisión difícil. "Debo hacerlo", pensó, su voz interior resonando con resolución. "Debo proteger a los que me aman, incluso si eso significa hacer algo que no puedo revertir". Mientras se preparaba para el desafío que estaba por venir, Marianne recordaba cada momento feliz compartido, cada sonrisa que había causado, cada promesa que había hecho. "Espero que mi elección sea la correcta", murmuró, antes de salir a enfrentar lo que venía.

en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

es_first_half: —Ahora puede ver cómo es su carácter: derrochador, licencioso, y peor aún que eso. Sabiéndolo, como yo lo he sabido desde hace ya muchas semanas, imagínese lo que debo haber sentido al ver a su hermana tan afecta a él como siempre, y cuando se me aseguró que iba a casarse con él; imagínese lo que habré sentido pensando en todas ustedes. Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontré sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque aún indeciso en cuanto a qué hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? No tenía esperanza alguna de intervenir con éxito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana aún podía mantener suficiente influencia sobre él para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¿quién sabe cuáles serían sus intenciones hacia ella? Cualesquiera hayan sido, sin embargo, puede que ahora ella se sienta agradecida de su situación, y sin duda más adelante lo estará, cuando la compare con la de mi pobre Eliza, cuando
es_second_half: piense en la situación miserable y desesperada de esta pobre niña y se la imagine con un afecto tan fuerte por él, tan fuerte como el que ella misma le tiene, y con un espíritu atormentado por las autorrecriminaciones, que la acompañarán durante toda su vida. Con toda seguridad esta comparación le servirá de algo. Sentirá que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deberán hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupación por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deberán reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreción para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qué efecto tendrá; y si no hubiera creído muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi corazón que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habría permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narración con la cual podría sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los demás.

The father, a man of considerable age, was eager to resolve the matter quickly, as he had pressing business to attend to. The children, though not present, were known to be of different ages, with Harry being the older of the two. The absence of the younger child added a layer of complexity to the problem, as their ages could not be directly compared. The investigator, a keen observer, began to ask questions about their habits, interests, and the details of their daily routines, hoping to uncover subtle clues that might reveal their exact ages. The father, visibly anxious yet trying to maintain composure, provided information that hinted at the disparities between his children. The investigator noted the father's mannerisms and the way he spoke of his children, which suggested a certain level of favoritism and perhaps a hint at the age gap. As the conversation progressed, the investigator subtly steered it towards topics that might reveal more about the children's lives, their interests, and their developmental stages. The investigator also considered the possibility of external factors such as school grades, friends, or even physical characteristics that could serve as indicators of their ages. Despite the absence of the younger child, the investigator was determined to piece together the puzzle using the information at hand and the subtle cues provided by the father's words and demeanor.

en_first_half: In a few minutes, however, Marianne was recovered enough to put an end to the bustle, and
en_second_half: sit down among the rest; though her spirits retained the impression of what had passed, the whole evening.
en_results: she insisted on their retiring to the drawing-room, where she could have a fire, and where she might be more
en_results_raw: she insisted on their retiring to the drawing-room, where she could have a fire, and where she might be more at ease. Her recovery was so sudden and complete, that both Mrs. Jennings and Willoughby were at a loss to account for it; and though they each had their own suspicions, neither chose to express them. Willoughby, however, could not forbear looking very grave and thoughtful, which drew from Marianne a quick glance, that seemed to say, "What are you thinking of?" but he immediately turned away, and endeavored to divert the attention of the whole party by proposing a game at cards. Marianne, though she joined in the game, did not seem quite herself; her spirits were high, but there was a want of her usual animation, and a restraint in her manner which her sister did not fail to observe. Elinor, who had been watching her closely, was at a loss to understand the cause. Was it the shock of the fall, or some other secret concern, that had so suddenly changed Marianne's usually lively and open disposition? The evening wore on, and Marianne gradually recovered her spirits, though she still avoided any conversation that might lead to the subject of her fall. Mrs. Jennings, in her usual manner, endeavored to keep up the spirits of the party by her lively anecdotes and playful remarks, which, however, were not quite so successful as usual, owing to the preoccupation of her daughter and Willoughby. Willoughby, on his part, seemed anxious to make amends for his earlier blunder, and was particularly attentive to Marianne, offering her his seat whenever she appeared fatigued, and taking every opportunity to engage her in conversation. Elinor watched this with a feeling of uneasiness, which she could not quite account for. Was it jealousy, or was it something more serious? As the evening wore on, and the party began to disperse, Marianne's spirits appeared to improve considerably. She joined in the general good-night greetings with her usual vivacity, and even ventured to tease Willoughby about his earlier awkwardness. Elinor, relieved but still puzzled, accompanied her sister to their rooms, pondering over the evening's events and the enigmatic behavior of both Marianne and Willoughby.

en_first_half: "I am sure I should have seen it in a moment, if Mrs. Ferrars had took a dislike to me. If she had only made me a formal courtesy, for instance, without saying a word, and never after had took any notice of me, and never
en_second_half: looked at me in a pleasant way—you know what I mean—if I had been treated in that forbidding sort of way, I should have gave it all up in despair. I could not have stood it. For where she DOES dislike, I know it is most violent."
en_results: such a thing as a private interview could have been asked of her. But to be actually invited into the room, and to have her talk to me as she did, and then to be sent away again, without a word of thanks, or even a look of recognition,
en_results_raw: such a thing as a private interview could have been asked of her. But to be actually invited into the room, and to have her talk to me as she did, and then to be sent away again, without a word of thanks, or even a look of recognition, is a degree of contempt which I never could have anticipated or borne. It is a reflection not only on my character, but on my understanding; for it implies that I am so utterly incapable of appreciating her motives or comprehending her reasons, that she might just as well have treated me with open scorn as with this cold indifference. It is a trial which I never could have faced, and I am thankful that it has never been my lot to encounter it. The consciousness of such an insult would have rankled in my mind, and made every moment of my life a torment. I am glad, therefore, that Mrs. Ferrars has spared me this trial; though I cannot help feeling a certain indignation at being thus treated as though I were a mere nonentity, unworthy of the slightest consideration. It is a bitter experience, and one which I hope never to repeat.

en_results_raw: She felt a sort of vague discomfort when she remained at home all day, as if she were neglecting some duty or missing an opportunity for enjoyment. Her walks, though often solitary, were never dull; they afforded her the chance to observe the changing seasons, the varied expressions of her fellow townspeople, and the picturesque details of the landscape. She found herself increasingly curious about the lives of those she passed, wondering about their stories, their joys, and their sorrows. The regular exercise also improved her health, granting her a sense of well-being that she had not anticipated. Moreover, these daily excursions provided her with a sense of purpose and structure, which was comforting in the otherwise predictable routine of her life. As she walked, Marianne often reflected on her own situation, her feelings for Willoughby, and her family's expectations, occasionally coming to new realizations about herself and her place in the world.

The sun was beginning to dip below the horizon, casting long shadows and painting the sky in hues of orange and pink. It was a beautiful end to a day filled with mixed emotions. Elinor sighed, her gaze lingering on the spot where he had disappeared. She knew that this farewell was not permanent; fate had a peculiar way of bringing people back into one's life. As she turned to enter the manor, her mind was a whirlwind of thoughts about the future and the uncertain paths that lay ahead. The sound of footsteps approaching from behind her snapped her out of her reverie. It was her cousin, Margaret, who had been observing the exchange from a distance. "Elinor, are you alright?" Margaret inquired, her voice laced with concern. Elinor forced a smile, trying to conceal the turmoil within. "I'm fine, just thinking," she replied, her voice slightly strained. Margaret eyed her skeptically but chose to let it go, understanding that Elinor's thoughts were often a labyrinthine maze. "There's a gathering in the drawing room," Margaret mentioned, her tone shifting to one of excitement. "Lady Catherine de Bourgh is expected to arrive soon, along with Mr. Darcy. It seems like a perfect opportunity to mingle and perhaps...settle some misunderstandings." Elinor nodded, her interest piqued despite her inner turmoil. The prospect of seeing Darcy again, under different circumstances, was both daunting and intriguing. She followed Margaret into the manor, her heart heavy yet hopeful for what the evening might bring.

en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."

Justo el tipo de muchacha que habría creído capaz de cautivar al pobre Edward. Apenas mi madre me contó todo el asunto, de inmediato me ofrecí— a hablarle, a disuadirlo de la unión; pero, según pude darme cuenta, ya era demasiado tarde para hacer algo, pues por desgracia no estuve ahí en los primeros momentos y no supe nada

De todas maneras le habría hecho ver las cosas a Edward con toda claridad. “Mi querido amigo”, le habría dicho, “piensa en lo que haces. Estás comprometiéndote en la más desafortunada unión, que toda tu familia desaprueba de manera unánime”. En fin, no puedo evitar pensar que habría encontrado alguna manera de lograrlo. Pero ahora es demasiado tarde. Debe estar muerto de hambre, sabe usted; con toda seguridad, absolutamente muerto de hambre.
